body.p: The guidance guidance recommends that staff use unique and strong passwords for every account you use.
To assist in remembering every password, it is recommended to use a password manager. A password manager’s function is to securely store different passwords in one place.
This guidance applies to all MoJ employees, contractors, executive agencies, associated bodies and third-party suppliers.
Please note that certain agencies may have additional or specific requirements. Check your local Intranet or consult your Line Manager for further information.
Password managers come in several forms, for example, including standalone applications and those integrated into browsers or operating system.
The MoJ provides a built-in browser password manager for use on supported browsers. When logging into a website, the browser will prompt you to save your credentials securely.
Additionally, there are a small number of specific MoJ teams that have access to the password manager 1Password for their work.

While a password manager stores many of your passwords, you still need to remember the primary password that grants access to the password manager application and allows you to view stored passwords. The primary password cannot be stored within the manager itself.

Key advantages of using a password manager include:
ability to quickly log into your accounts
only the primary password needs to be remembered, rather than multiple complex passwords
all stored passwords are encrypted for secure access
avoids the need to reset forgotten passwords
The MoJ recommends the following good practices when using a password manager:

ul.li: Use the built-in browser password manager to store passwords securely
Set a strong primary password by creating a password that is least 14 characters long by combining memorable multiple words together. An example is CyberSecurityRules! or Green8Duckmoonburger
Store strong and unique passwords that meet the MoJ’s password guidance
Avoid sharing your passwords with others
Promptly install software updates to maintain security
Avoid storing passwords in unsecure formats, such as Notepad or Word documents
